content.statement: vascular:mesenteric:mes-003-chronic is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Mesenteric that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding vascular:mesenteric:mes-003-chronic helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of vascular:mesenteric:mes-003-chronic include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of vascular:mesenteric:mes-003-chronic.

clinical_triad.postprandial_pain: Dull, crampy periumbilical pain 15-60 min after eating, lasting 1-3 hours
clinical_triad.food_fear: Sitophobia - patients eat less to avoid pain

pathophysiology.mechanism: Mesenteric blood flow cannot meet increased postprandial demand
pathophysiology.vessels_involved: Usually 2-3 vessel disease required due to collaterals
pathophysiology.progression: May progress to acute mesenteric ischemia (acute-on-chronic)

diagnosis.clinical_suspicion: High in patients with classic triad and atherosclerotic disease

duplex.postprandial: Normally SMA flow increases 50-100% after meal; blunted in CMI

diagnosis.CTA_MRA: Gold standard for anatomic assessment and planning

endovascular.stenting: First-line for most patients; SMA is priority
endovascular.limitations: Lower long-term patency (50-80% at 5 years), in-stent restenosis

surgical.bypass: Antegrade from supraceliac aorta or retrograde from iliac
surgical.indications: Endovascular failure, hostile anatomy, young patients

treatment.medical: Optimize nutrition, small frequent meals, treat atherosclerotic risk factors

definition.@value: Chronic ischemic syndrome caused by mesenteric artery stenosis, characterized by postprandial pain, food fear, and weight loss, typically requiring multi-vessel disease due to collateral networks.

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Recognize the classic triad of chronic mesenteric ischemia
Understand why multi-vessel disease is usually required
Apply duplex criteria for mesenteric stenosis
clinical_pearls: Classic triad: postprandial pain + food fear + weight loss
Usually need 2 of 3 vessels stenosed due to excellent collaterals
Duplex: SMA PSV >275 and celiac PSV >200 suggest significant stenosis
Bypass has better patency than stenting (80-90% vs 50-80% at 5 years)
May present as acute-on-chronic if thromboses
